newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX electricity ends higher despite softer cash.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX electricity ends higher despite softer cash.

text.p: NYMEX electricity futures settled higher Thursday in a choppy session despite softer spot physical prices in the West.
"We can't seem to rally up and and we can't seem to sell off," said a Houston futures said, referring to Wednesday's rangebound activity that finished in a late slide.
Market sources said the power complex is struggling to find a direction amid the lack of fresh fundamental news and rangebound trading in natural gas futures.
July California-Oregon Border (COB) futures settled up 39 cents at $17.08 a megawatt hour (MWh) after bouncing in a 40 cent range.
August COB finished up four cents at $20.59. Deferred COB months ended down 21 cents to up 10 cents.
July Palo Verde (PV) settled up 27 cents at $26.76, about the middle of today's $26.55-27.10 trading range.
August PV finished up 11 cents at $28.91. Other active COB contracts ended mixed.
NYMEX July Henry Hub natgas futures settled up 0.9 cent at $2.080 per million British thermal units.
Under forecast of mild temperatures in the West, firm, peak Friday power prices at COB held steady at $14.50-15.50, while those at PV slipped to $21.00-22.50 from $22.75-23.75.

Several coal-fired power units in the West are expected to resume operation over the next several days: a 450 megawatt (MW) unit at the San Juan coal-fired plant in New Mexico, a 190 unit at the Hayden coal-fired station in Colorado and a 670 MW unit at the Centralia coal-fired station in Washington.
In the meantime, a 875 MW unit at the Intermountain coal-fired power plant in Utah is said to shut Friday through Sunday to repair a tube leak.station
Forecasters called temperatures in the Northwest to run near to above normal next week with bouts of unsettled weather conditions.
Fair and warm weather was expected to stay in the Southwest with readings averaging three to six degrees Fahrenheit above normal through the middle of next week.
Market sources said power futures will likely continue their rangebound pattern Friday.

Separately, a Western Systems Coordinating Council committee is expected to propose next week a summertime rating for the Pacific Intertie of 6,900 MW, down from the current springtime limit of 7,200 MW.
NYMEX estimated 786 COB and 751 PV contracts were sold, compared with Wednesday's 854 COB and 682 PV lots.
